channel.title: Maths problem >.< 2 questions (changing the subjects)
channel.description:
Ok these are the only 2 questions im stumped on...
you have to change the subject to x:
Y=1/2(x-3)
and
Y=3/4(x-1)
thanks :p show working pl0x, i got totally stumped, teacher doesnt teach to well...

item.title: Maths problem >.< 2 questions (changing the subjects)
item.dc:creator: @sidishere sidishere
item.description:
@sidishere wrote:

[quote=“BobDole81, post:2, topic:92674”]1)

y = 1 / [2(x - 3)]
y = (1/2) * 1/(x - 3)
2y = 1/(x - 3)
2y(x - 3) = 1
x - 3 = 1/2y
x = (1/2y) + 3

y = 3 / [4(x - 1)]
y = (3/4) * 1/(x - 1)
(4/3)y = 1/(x - 1)
(4/3)y(x - 1) = 1
x - 1 = 1/(4/3)y
x = (3/4y) + 1

Tell me if that’s wrong…I may have misinterpreted your questions (didn’t know whether the (x - 3) and (x - 1) were in the denominator or numerator)[/quote]

look pretty good to me

Read full topic

item.title: Maths problem >.< 2 questions (changing the subjects)
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I was making it more complicated then But the workings are roughly the same as what I did above - I’ll be a bit more clear with them this time though:

y = ½(x - 3)
2 * y = ½(x-3) * 2
2y = x - 3
x = 2y + 3

y = ¾(x - 1)
(4/3) * y = ¾(x - 1) * (4/3)
4y/3 = x - 1
x = 4y/3 - 1 (Note that 1 = 3/3)
x = 4y/3 - 3/3
x = (4y - 3) / 3

Hope that helps

Read full topic

item.title: Maths problem >.< 2 questions (changing the subjects)
item.dc:creator: @fedexer -fedexer-
item.description:
@fedexer wrote:

slightly wrong their bob we know the final answer (me and a mate, got same h/w lol, and we have answers in the back of text book, but we need to show working… if i supply the answer it might help you with the working)

Question : Y=½(x-3)
Answer: X = 2y + 3

and

Question : Y=¾(x-1)

Answer: X = 4y+3
----
3

(sorry for the one above … couldnt set it out right on mopar lol )

well if you can find the working out for that it would be swell
P.S (x-1) and (x-3) are numerators

item.title: Maths problem >.< 2 questions (changing the subjects)
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

y = 1 / [2(x - 3)]
y = (1/2) * 1/(x - 3)
2y = 1/(x - 3)
2y(x - 3) = 1
x - 3 = 1/2y
x = (1/2y) + 3

y = 3 / [4(x - 1)]
y = (3/4) * 1/(x - 1)
(4/3)y = 1/(x - 1)
(4/3)y(x - 1) = 1
x - 1 = 1/(4/3)y
x = (3/4y) + 1

Tell me if that’s wrong…I may have misinterpreted your questions (didn’t know whether the (x - 3) and (x - 1) were in the denominator or numerator)
